summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting a proffer interview with a former Bureau of Prisons Corrections Officer from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The officer provides detailed information about his career, duties on the Disturbance Control Team and in the Special Housing Unit, procedures for handling contraband and inmates, and events surrounding a major facility shakedown in February 2020. He also discusses being placed on administrative leave and his limited knowledge of Jeffrey Epstein's death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the inmate whose death brought a spotlight on the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the MCC.

persons.name: Darden
persons.context: Identified as the Lieutenant (LT) at the MCC during the time period discussed, particularly around Epstein's death.

events.title: Proffer Interview
events.description: A former MCC Corrections Officer is interviewed by the U.S. Attorney's Office and FBI under a proffer agreement, providing information about his career and events at the MCC.

events.title: MCC Disturbance Control Team Activation and Shakedown
events.description: The MCC's DCT was activated at the end of February 2020 for a major, last-minute operation involving shakedowns of inmate units, reportedly due to a potential gun in the facility. The team worked extended hours searching for contraband.

events.title: Interviewee Placed on Administrative Leave
events.description: The interviewee was placed on administrative leave, which he believes was retaliatory for an argument with an Associate Warden and his role in the DCT quitting after the February 2020 shakedown.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein is referenced as an event that brought increased focus and scrutiny to the Special Housing Unit at the MCC.

keyFacts: The interviewee was a long-term Corrections Officer and Acting Lieutenant at the MCC, working on the Disturbance Control Team and in internal security.

He was off duty on the day of Jeffrey Epstein's death and states he has no knowledge of any special restrictions put in place in the SHU afterwards, though the facility's focus shifted to the SHU due to the spotlight from Epstein's death.

He describes a major, chaotic DCT activation and facility-wide shakedown in late February 2020, prompted by reports of a potential gun, which led to his DCT team quitting and him being placed on administrative leave.
He acknowledges passing an inspected, permitted item between inmates in the SHU on video but states he would not pass contraband.
The document reveals internal MCC procedures for the SHU, contraband handling, and officer-inmate interactions, including the role of gang-affiliated inmates in unit dynamics.
